questions.text:
#### Q1. Which type cast preserves the mathematical value in all cases?

- %OPTION% i64 as i32
- %OPTION% usize as u64
- %OPTION% i32 as i64
- %OPTION% f64 as f32

#### Q3. Which choice is not a scalar data type?

- %OPTION% integer
- %OPTION% float
- %OPTION% boolean
- %OPTION% tuple

#### Q4. **\_** cannot be destructured.

- %OPTION% Traits
- %OPTION% Tuples
- %OPTION% Enums
- %OPTION% Structs

[reference](https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/2909-destructuring-assignment.html)

#### Q5. Which `cargo` command checks a program for error without creating a binary executable?

- %OPTION% cargo --version
- %OPTION% cargo init
- %OPTION% cargo build
- %OPTION% cargo check

#### Q6. The term _box_ and related phrases such as _boxing a value_ are often used when relating to memory layout. What does _box_ refer to?

- %OPTION% It's creating a pointer on the heap that points to a value on the stack.
- %OPTION% It's creating a pointer on the stack that points to a value on the heap.
- %OPTION% It's creating a memory guard around values to prevent illegal access.
- %OPTION% It's an abstraction that refers to ownership. "Boxed" values are clearly labelled.

#### Q8. Using the `?` operator at the end of an expression is equivalent to **\_**.

- %OPTION% a match pattern that branches into True or False
- %OPTION% calling ok_error()
- %OPTION% calling panic!()
- %OPTION% a match pattern that may result an early return

#### Q9. Which is valid syntax for defining an array of i32 values?

- %OPTION% Array<i32>::with_capacity(10)
- %OPTION% [i32]
- %OPTION% Array<i32>::new(10)
- %OPTION% [i32; 10]

#### Q11. The smart pointers Rc and Arc provide reference counting. What is the API for incrementing a reference count?

- %OPTION% .add()
- %OPTION% .incr()
- %OPTION% .clone()
- %OPTION% .increment()

[reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch15-04-rc.html)

#### Q12. What happens when an error occurs that is being handled by the question mark (?) operator?

- %OPTION% The error is reported and execution continues.
- %OPTION% An exception is raised. The effect(s) of the exception are defined by the error! macro.
- %OPTION% The program panics immediately.
- %OPTION% Rust attempts to convert the error to the local function's error type and return it as Result::Err. If that fails, the program panics.

#### Q13. Which comment syntax is not legal?

- %OPTION% `/*`
- %OPTION% `#`
- %OPTION% `//!`
- %OPTION% `//`

#### Q14. In matching patterns, values are ignored with \_.

- %OPTION% `.ignore()`
- %OPTION% `an underscore (_)`
- %OPTION% ..
- %OPTION% skip

#### Q15. Defining a \_ requires a lifetime parameter.

- %OPTION% function that ends the lifetime of one of its arguments
- %OPTION% struct that contains a reference to a value
- %OPTION% function with a generic argument
- %OPTION% struct that contains a reference to a boxed value

[Rust book reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch10-03-lifetime-syntax.html#lifetime-annotations-in-struct-definitions)

#### Q19. Which statement about lifetimes is false?

- %OPTION% Lifetimes were redundantly specified in previous version of Rust.
- %OPTION% Lifetimes are specified when a struct is holding a reference to a value.
- %OPTION% Lifetimes are specified when certain values must outlive others.
- %OPTION% Lifetimes are always inferred by the compiler.

#### Q20. When used as a return type, which Rust type plays a similar role to Python's `None`, JavaScript's `null`, or the `void` type in C/C++?

- %OPTION% `!`
- %OPTION% `None`
- %OPTION% `Null`
- %OPTION% `()`

#### Q21. To convert a `Result` to an `Option`, which method should you use?

- %OPTION% `.as_option()`
- %OPTION% `.ok()`
- %OPTION% `.to_option()`
- %OPTION% `.into()`

#### Q22. Which statement about the `Clone` and `Copy` traits is false?

- %OPTION% `Copy` is enabled for primitive, built-in types.
- %OPTION% Without `Copy`, Rust applies move semantics to a type's access.
- %OPTION% When using `Clone`, copying data is explicit.
- %OPTION% Until a type implements either `Copy` or `Clone`, its internal data cannot be copied.

[ref from stack overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41413336/do-all-primitive-types-implement-the-copy-trait)

#### Q23. Why does this code _not_ compile?

```rust
fn returns_closure() -> dyn Fn(i32) -> i32 {
    |x| x + 1
}
```

- %OPTION% The returned `fn` pointer and value need to be represented by another trait.
- %OPTION% Closures are types, so they cannot be returned directly from a function.
- %OPTION% Closures are types and can be returned only if the concrete trait is implemented.
- %OPTION% Closures are represented by traits, so they cannot be a return type.

[Rust book reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch19-05-advanced-functions-and-closures.html#returning-closures)

#### Q24. What smart pointer is used to allow multiple ownership of a value in various threads?

- %OPTION% `Arc<T>`
- %OPTION% `Box<T>`
- %OPTION% Both `Arc<T>` and `Rc<T>` are multithread safe.
- %OPTION% `Rc<T>`

[Rust book reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch16-03-shared-state.html?highlight=arc%3CT%3E#atomic-reference-counting-with-arct)

#### Q25. Which types are _not_ allowed within an enum variant's body?

- %OPTION% zero-sized types
- %OPTION% structs
- %OPTION% trait objects
- %OPTION% floating-point numbers

[Reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/types/trait-object.html)

#### Q27. Your application requires a single copy of some data type T to be held in memory that can be accessed by multiple threads. What is the thread-safe wrapper type?

- %OPTION% `Mutex<Arc<T>>`
- %OPTION% `Rc<Mutex<T>>`
- %OPTION% `Arc<Mutex<T>>`
- %OPTION% `Mutex<Rc<T>>`

[Rust book reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch16-03-shared-state.html#atomic-reference-counting-with-arct)

#### Q30. Which choice is _not_ valid loop syntax?

- %OPTION% `loop`
- %OPTION% `for`
- %OPTION% `while`
- %OPTION% `do`

#### Q31. How do you construct a value of `Status` that is initialized to `Waiting`?

```rust
enum Status {
    Waiting,
    Busy,
    Error(String),
}
```

- %OPTION% `let s = Enum::new(Status::Waiting);`
- %OPTION% `let s = new Status::Waiting;`
- %OPTION% `let s = Status::Waiting;`
- %OPTION% `let s = Status::new(Waiting);`

#### Q32. Which statement about enums is false?

- %OPTION% Enums are useful in matching patterns.
- %OPTION% Option is an enum type.
- %OPTION% Enum variants can have different types with associated data.
- %OPTION% the term _enum_ is short for _enummap_

#### Q33. What does an underscore (\_) indicate when used as pattern?

- %OPTION% It matches everything.
- %OPTION% It matches underscores.
- %OPTION% It matches any value that has a length of 1.
- %OPTION% It matches nothing.

#### Q34. What is a safe operation on a `std::cell:UnsafeCell<T>`?

- %OPTION% A `&mut T` reference is allowed. However it may not cpexists with any other references. and may be created only in single-threaded code.
- %OPTION% `UnsafeCell<T>` provides thread-safety. Therefore, creating `&T` references from multiple threads is safe.
- %OPTION% The only safe operation is the `.get()` method, which returns only a raw pointer.
- %OPTION% Non. `UnsafeCell<T>` only allows code that would otherwise need unsafe blocks to be written in safe code.

[Reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/cell/struct.UnsafeCell.html)

#### Q35. Generics are useful when you **\_**.

- %OPTION% need to reduce code duplication by concretizing values and restricting parameters in functions
- %OPTION% need to reduce code duplication by abstracting values further, such as in function parameters
- %OPTION% need a supertrait
- %OPTION% are not sure if you need a specific kind of trait

#### Q36. How do you create a Rust project on the command-line?

- %OPTION% cargo new
- %OPTION% rustup init
- %OPTION% cargo start
- %OPTION% rust new-project

en.TITLE: Skill Assessments Quizzes
en.DESC:
Collection of questions and answers on different subjects aimed to help
you test your knowledge before an important job interview!

Data from __data__. UI by __bandinopla__

es.DESC:
